Hi, Jeff,
First of all, very good tutorial.
I'm sure several new devs are going to start coding from this material.

Given that, here it goes a little comment on productive data practices.

In `db/tasks.py` you are defaulting to production:
`DB_URL = f"{DATABASE_URL}_test" if os.environ.get("TESTING") else DATABASE_URL`

And IMO that should never be the case. A lot of things can go wrong before that validation: a dev deletes `os.environ["TESTING"] = "1"` from `apply_migrations`, someone forget to set it up in .env, or even a typo in `TESTING` can send the tests to prod.

Everything should go to non-productive environments EXCEPT WHEN WE DECIDE OTHERWISE.

For example, we avoid that risk changing the env var name to the opposite:
* `DB_URL = DATABASE_URL if os.environ.get("PRODUCTION") else f"{DATABASE_URL}_test"`
* `os.environ["PRODUCTION"] = "1"`

I also like testing, BTW. Sets a very good example someone publicly saying that enjoys it.

Thanks for the work, very good :) :)

Hi Jeff, 

Thank you for this great resource! It's well written and very helpful. 

Just adding on to what Darryl commented, I am having the same problem. I tried adding psycopg2-binary==2.8.6 to the requirements.txt, but that did not work either. Only manually running "pip install pyscopg2-binary" did the trick.

Another issue was "docker-compose exec db psql -h localhost -U postgres --dbname=postgres". After running it nothing happens.

Instead, I ran "docker exec -it [db container id] psql -h localhost -U postgres --dbname=postgres" and it worked. I'm a rookie, this is all very new to me and I'm not sure why exactly one works but not the other, but I thought it might be useful to yourself and others to give a heads up.

It's usually an error attached to OsX (at least in my case), I fix that error creating an ubuntu container (in the Dockerfile) like this:

FROM ubuntu:latest

USER root

WORKDIR /backend

ENV PYTHONDONTWRITEBYTECODE 1
ENV PYTHONBUFFERED 1

RUN apt-get update \
  && apt-get install -y python3-pip python3-dev \

  && cd /usr/local/bin \
  && ln -s /usr/bin/python3 python \
  && pip3 install --upgrade pip

COPY ./requirements.txt /backend/requirements.txt
RUN pip install -r requirements.txt
COPY . /backend
Very cool, very professional, very awesome! love from china.

Hello, before anything I want to thank you for this tutorial series, it has been really helpful. 

I have a question about the dependency injection and the repositories. Let's say that my application grows in complexity and the current organization is getting clumsy, would it be a good idea to create a new type of dependency that isolates the bussiness logic while leaving the routes handling only the requests and the repositories handling only the data access? Because it seems that the auth dependency here does exactly that. 

For example, I think an interesting approach would be to create a Login and Register services, just like the AuthService, move all the authentication stuff from the UsersRepository and connect all together like `route("/register") -> RegisterService -> UsersRepository`, leaving the users repo with the single responsibility of data access on the User model.

Hi, this tutorial is very nice!! I have one question. 

It seems that you are not actually using the postgres_container that you set up in conftest.py in tests. The "db_url" used in "run_migrations_online()" must resolve to the name of the new container URL.

We can actually comment out conftest.py as follows and add

```python
    try:
        os.environ["DB_SUFFIX"] = "_test"
        alembic.command.upgrade(config, "head")
        yield container
        # alembic.command.downgrade(config, "base")
    finally:
        pass
        # remove container
        # docker.kill(container["Id"])
        # docker.remove_container(container["Id"])
```

After running pytest, we can see that the test record has been inserted into the main postgres. And the new container does not CREATE the postgres-test.

thank you in advance.
Hi Jeff, Thanks for this tutorial.  When I run the test this issue is throwing "AttributeError: 'UsersRepository' object has no attribute 'profile_repo'".

It does provide previous and next links as seen [here](https://github.com/uriyyo/fastapi-pagination/blob/main/fastapi_pagination/links/bases.py), but the default version using the databases package (or asyncpg or any other option in the [ext](https://github.com/uriyyo/fastapi-pagination/tree/main/fastapi_pagination/ext) directory) only offer offset and limit based pagination as seen [here](https://github.com/uriyyo/fastapi-pagination/blob/main/fastapi_pagination/ext/sqlalchemy.py) .

I got an error when trying to run "alembic upgrade head". Error was "ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'psycopg2'"
I fixed it by running "pip install psycopg2-binary". 
So I added:
psycopg2-binary==2.8.6
to your requirements.txt. v2.8.6 is what it installed automatically with pip install hence used that in requirements.txt.
Great catch! Updating the code now.

Hi, this tutorial has been super informative and well written, thank you!
I do have a question about the SQL to get profile by username. Is there a particular reason why you use a subquery instead of just where u.username = :username ?

Thank you very much! Glad you're liking it.

The `"@@"` prefix in the action type string is arbitrary, and not necessary. I include them as it's just useful when looking at the redux dev tools debugger, so that I can know with a quick glance which slice an action is coming from. If you take them out, everything will work the same way! 

That's why it's nice to use constants for the action types instead of strings all over the place. Standardizes the process quite a bit.

Of course! Glad you're enjoying them.

And that's a good question. Since we're accessing values from the `users` and `profiles` tables, it's totally possible to do that without a subquery. Initially I was only querying the `profiles` table, and needed the `user_id` from the `users` table. Now that I'm using both, it's probably more efficient to do something like:

```
SELECT p.id,
           u.email AS email,
           u.username AS username,
           full_name,
           phone_number,
           bio,
           image,
           user_id,
           p.created_at,
           p.updated_at
    FROM users u
        INNER JOIN profiles p 
        ON p.user_id = u.id
    WHERE u.username = :username;
```

Good catch.
Great post and thanks for all your effort! Looking forward the read the rest of the series.
